natural problem: Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.

We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}

&(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y z. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> z \<in> {1..6} \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> x \<noteq> z \<and> y \<noteq> z
                \<longrightarrow> p {x, y, z} = (if x + y > z \<and> x + z > y \<and> y + z > x then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "0 \<le> p x \<and> p x \<le> 1"
shows  "(\<Sum>x\<in>{x. \<exists>y z. y \<in> {1..6} \<and> z \<in> {1..6} \<and> x = {y, z, z} \<and> y \<noteq> z}. p x) / ((6 choose 3) * 3!) = 7 / 20"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y z. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> z \<in> {1..6} \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> x \<noteq> z \<and> y \<noteq> z
                \<longrightarrow> p {x, y, z} = (if x + y > z \<and> x + z > y \<and> y + z > x then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "0 \<le> p x \<and> p x \<le> 1"
shows  "(\<Sum>x\<in>{x. \<exists>y z. y \<in> {1..6} \<and> z \<in> {1..6} \<and> x = {y, z, z} \<and> y \<noteq> z}. p x) / ((6 choose 3) * 3!) = 7 / 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider a function p that takes a set of three distinct numbers from 1 to 6. The function outputs 1 if the numbers can form the sides of a triangle, and 0 otherwise. What is the probability that a randomly selected set of three distinct numbers from 1 to 6 can form the sides of a triangle? The final answer is $\frac{7}{20}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sides :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> sides i \<and> sides i \<le> 6"
and h1 : "distinct [sides 1, sides 2, sides 3]"
and h2 : "sides 1 + sides 2 > sides 3 \<and> sides 2 + sides 3 > sides 1 \<and> sides 3 + sides 1 > sides 2"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. x = [sides 1, sides 2, sides 3]) = 7 / 20"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes sides :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> sides i \<and> sides i \<le> 6"
and h1 : "distinct [sides 1, sides 2, sides 3]"
and h2 : "sides 1 + sides 2 > sides 3 \<and> sides 2 + sides 3 > sides 1 \<and> sides 3 + sides 1 > sides 2"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. x = [sides 1, sides 2, sides 3]) = 7 / 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Assume there is a 3-sided dice where each side can take an integer value between 1 and 6, inclusive. If the numbers on the three sides are distinct and form a triangle (i.e., the sum of any two sides is greater than the third side), what is the probability that a roll shows a particular configuration of [side 1, side 2, side 3]? The final answer is 7/20.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "b \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h2 : "c \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h3 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h4 : "a \<noteq> c"
and h5 : "b \<noteq> c"
and h6 : "a + b > c"
and h7 : "a + c > b"
and h8 : "b + c > a"
shows  "prob {a, b, c} = 7 / 20"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "b \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h2 : "c \<in> {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h3 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h4 : "a \<noteq> c"
and h5 : "b \<noteq> c"
and h6 : "a + b > c"
and h7 : "a + c > b"
and h8 : "b + c > a"
shows  "prob {a, b, c} = 7 / 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If $a$, $b$, and $c$ are distinct integers from the set $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$ that can form a triangle (i.e., $a + b > c$, $a + c > b$, and $b + c > a$), what is the probability that a randomly chosen triplet $(a, b, c)$ satisfies these conditions? The answer is $\frac{7}{20}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (card { (a,b,c) | a b c. {a,b,c} ⊆ {1..6} ∧ a < b + c ∧ b < a + c ∧ c < a + b }) / (card { (a,b,c) | a b c. {a,b,c} ⊆ {1..6} } )"
shows  "p = 7 / 20"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (card { (a,b,c) | a b c. {a,b,c} ⊆ {1..6} ∧ a < b + c ∧ b < a + c ∧ c < a + b }) / (card { (a,b,c) | a b c. {a,b,c} ⊆ {1..6} } )"
shows  "p = 7 / 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: What is the probability that three numbers chosen randomly and without replacement from the set {1,2,3,4,5,6} will be the lengths of the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{7}{20}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 6"
and h1 : "b \<ge> 1 \<and> b \<le> 6"
and h2 : "c \<ge> 1 \<and> c \<le> 6"
and h3 : "a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c"
and h4 : "a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a"
shows  "7/20 = (card {a, b, c} / card {1..6} choose 3)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 6"
and h1 : "b \<ge> 1 \<and> b \<le> 6"
and h2 : "c \<ge> 1 \<and> c \<le> 6"
and h3 : "a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c"
and h4 : "a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a"
shows  "7/20 = (card {a, b, c} / card {1..6} choose 3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If $a$, $b$, and $c$ are distinct integers such that $1 \leq a, b, c \leq 6$ and the sum of any two of $a$, $b$, and $c$ is greater than the third one, what is the probability that this can occur? The final answer is $\frac{7}{20}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and P Q :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 6 \<and> n \<noteq> n + 1 \<and> n \<noteq> n + 2 \<longrightarrow> Q n"
and h2 : "card {n. P n} = 6"
and h3 : "card {n. Q n} = 3"
shows  "real (card {n. Q n}) / real (card {n. P n}) = 7 / 20"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and P Q :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P n"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<le> 6 \<and> n \<noteq> n + 1 \<and> n \<noteq> n + 2 \<longrightarrow> Q n"
and h2 : "card {n. P n} = 6"
and h3 : "card {n. Q n} = 3"
shows  "real (card {n. Q n}) / real (card {n. P n}) = 7 / 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Let P and Q be properties of natural numbers such that every number less than or equal to 6 has property P, and only the numbers that are less than or equal to 6 and are not successors of themselves or the number following their successor have property Q. If the count of numbers with property P is 6 and the count of numbers with property Q is 3, what is the ratio of the count of numbers with property Q to the count of numbers with property P? The final answer is 7/20.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "b \<in> {1..6}"
and h2 : "c \<in> {1..6}"
and h3 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h4 : "a \<noteq> c"
and h5 : "b \<noteq> c"
and h6 : "a + b > c"
and h7 : "a + c > b"
and h8 : "b + c > a"
shows  "card {(a, b, c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a} / card {(a, b, c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c} = 7 / 20"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "b \<in> {1..6}"
and h2 : "c \<in> {1..6}"
and h3 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h4 : "a \<noteq> c"
and h5 : "b \<noteq> c"
and h6 : "a + b > c"
and h7 : "a + c > b"
and h8 : "b + c > a"
shows  "card {(a, b, c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a} / card {(a, b, c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c} = 7 / 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Three distinct numbers are randomly chosen from the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. What is the probability that the three numbers can form the sides of a triangle? The final answer is $\frac{7}{20}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c"
and h2 : "a < b + c \<and> b < a + c \<and> c < a + b"
shows  "card { (a,b,c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a < b + c \<and> b < a + c \<and> c < a + b } / card { (a,b,c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c } = 7 / 20"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c"
and h2 : "a < b + c \<and> b < a + c \<and> c < a + b"
shows  "card { (a,b,c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a < b + c \<and> b < a + c \<and> c < a + b } / card { (a,b,c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c } = 7 / 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A, B, and C each roll a fair six-sided die. If all three rolls are different and form a triangle (each roll is less than the sum of the other two), what is the probability that this happens? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{7}{20}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b c. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> P a b c = ((a + b > c) \<and> (a + c > b) \<and> (b + c > a))"
shows  "prob P = 7 / 20"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: int and P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b c. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<longrightarrow> P a b c = ((a + b > c) \<and> (a + c > b) \<and> (b + c > a))"
shows  "prob P = 7 / 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: If $a$, $b$, and $c$ are distinct integers from 1 to 6, what is the probability that the sum of any two of them is greater than the third one? The final answer is $\frac{7}{20}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (card { (a,b,c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a } / card { (a,b,c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c })"
shows  "p = 7 / 20"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Dakota randomly selected three different integers $1$ through $6.$ What is the probability that the three numbers selected could be the sides of a triangle? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{7}{20}
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6 \cdot 5 \cdot 4}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1} = 20$ possible sets of three different integers.
 We need to figure out how many of these could be the sides of a triangle. Clearly, none of the sides can be $1,$ since that would violate the Triangle Inequality. As for the rest, it is quite a simple matter to just list them all in an organized fashion: \begin{align}
 &(2, 3, 4)\\ &(2, 4, 5)\\ &(2, 5, 6)\\ &(3, 4, 5)\\ &(3, 4, 6)\\ &(3, 5, 6)\\ &(4, 5, 6) \end{align} Therefore, there are $7$ possible sets of numbers that could be sides of a triangle, out of $20$ possible sets, so our answer is $\boxed{\frac{7}{20}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (card { (a,b,c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a } / card { (a,b,c). a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c })"
shows  "p = 7 / 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Determine the probability $p$ that three distinct numbers $a$, $b$, and $c$, each ranging from 1 to 6, form a triangle (i.e., satisfy the triangle inequality $a + b > c$, $a + c > b$, and $b + c > a$). The final answer is $\frac{7}{20}$.
